about.summary: The stratification of univariate populations under stratified sampling designs is implemented according to Khan et al. (2002) <doi:10.1177/0008068320020518> and Khan et al. (2015) <doi:10.1080/02664763.2015.1018674> in this library. It determines the Optimum Strata Boundaries (OSB) and Optimum Sample Sizes (OSS) for the study variable, y, using the best-fit frequency distribution of a survey variable (if data is available) or a hypothetical distribution (if data is not available). The method formulates the problem of determining the OSB as mathematical programming problem which is solved by using a dynamic programming technique. If a dataset of the population is available to the surveyor, the method estimates its best-fit distribution and determines the OSB and OSS under Neyman allocation directly. When the dataset is not available, stratification is made based on the assumption that the values of the study variable, y, are available as hypothetical realizations of proxy values of y from recent surveys. Thus, it requires certain distributional assumptions about the study variable. At present, it handles stratification for the populations where the study variable follows a continuous distribution, namely, Pareto, Triangular, Right-triangular, Weibull, Gamma, Exponential, Uniform, Normal, Log-normal and Cauchy distributions.

The stratification of univariate populations under stratified sampling designs is implemented according to Khan et al. (2002) <doi:10.1177/0008068320020518> and Khan et al. (2015) <doi:10.1080/02664763.2015.1018674> in this library. It determines the Optimum Strata Boundaries (OSB) and Optimum Sample Sizes (OSS) for the study variable, y, using the best-fit frequency distribution of a survey variable (if data is available) or a hypothetical distribution (if data is not available). The method formulates the problem of determining the OSB as mathematical programming problem which is solved by using a dynamic programming technique. If a dataset of the population is available to the surveyor, the method estimates its best-fit distribution and determines the OSB and OSS under Neyman allocation directly. When the dataset is not available, stratification is made based on the assumption that the values of the study variable, y, are available as hypothetical realizations of proxy values of y from recent surveys. Thus, it requires certain distributional assumptions about the study variable. At present, it handles stratification for the populations where the study variable follows a continuous distribution, namely, Pareto, Triangular, Right-triangular, Weibull, Gamma, Exponential, Uniform, Normal, Log-normal and Cauchy distributions.

name: r-stratifyr
raw_meta_yaml:
{% set version = '1.0-3' %}
{% set posix = 'm2-' if win else '' %}
{% set native = 'm2w64-' if win else '' %}

package:
  name: r-stratifyr
  version: {{ version|replace("-", "_") }}

source:
  url:
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/stratifyR_{{ version }}.tar.gz
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/Archive/stratifyR/stratifyR_{{ version }}.tar.gz
  sha256: 588397c155d68426e8f4f652adb7ca7bd37fcee0d2bf834fc63920d0a1d777cd

build:
  merge_build_host: True  # [win]
  number: 2
  noarch: generic
  rpaths:
    - lib/R/lib/
    - lib/

requirements:
  build:
    - {{ posix }}zip               # [win]
    - cross-r-base {{ r_base }}    # [build_platform != target_platform]
  host:
    - r-base
    - r-actuar
    - r-fitdistrplus
    - r-mc2d
    - r-triangle
    - r-zipfr
  run:
    - r-base
    - r-actuar
    - r-fitdistrplus
    - r-mc2d
    - r-triangle
    - r-zipfr

test:
  commands:
    - $R -e "library('stratifyR')"           # [not win]
    - "\"%R%\" -e \"library('stratifyR')\""  # [win]

about:
  home: https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=stratifyR
  license: GPL-2.0-only
  summary: The stratification of univariate populations under stratified sampling designs is
    implemented according to Khan et al. (2002) <doi:10.1177/0008068320020518> and Khan
    et al. (2015) <doi:10.1080/02664763.2015.1018674> in this library. It determines
    the Optimum Strata Boundaries (OSB) and Optimum Sample Sizes (OSS) for the study
    variable, y, using the best-fit frequency distribution of a survey variable (if
    data is available) or a hypothetical distribution (if data is not available). The
    method formulates the problem of determining the OSB as mathematical programming
    problem which is solved by using a dynamic programming technique. If a dataset of
    the population is available to the surveyor, the method estimates its best-fit distribution
    and determines the OSB and OSS under Neyman allocation directly. When the dataset
    is not available, stratification is made based on the assumption that the values
    of the study variable, y, are available as hypothetical realizations of proxy values
    of y from recent surveys. Thus, it requires certain distributional assumptions about
    the study variable. At present, it handles stratification for the populations where
    the study variable follows a continuous distribution, namely, Pareto, Triangular,
    Right-triangular, Weibull, Gamma, Exponential, Uniform, Normal, Log-normal and Cauchy
    distributions.
  license_family: GPL2
  license_file:
    - '{{ environ["PREFIX"] }}/lib/R/share/licenses/GPL-2'

extra:
  recipe-maintainers:
    - conda-forge/r
    - mfansler

# Package: stratifyR
# Type: Package

# Description: The stratification of univariate populations under stratified sampling designs is implemented according to Khan et al. (2002) <doi:10.1177/0008068320020518> and Khan et al. (2015) <doi:10.1080/02664763.2015.1018674> in this library. It determines the Optimum Strata Boundaries (OSB) and Optimum Sample Sizes (OSS) for the study variable, y, using the best-fit frequency distribution of a survey variable (if data is available) or a hypothetical distribution (if data is not available). The method formulates the problem of determining the OSB as mathematical programming problem which is solved by using a dynamic programming technique. If a dataset of the population is available to the surveyor, the method estimates its best-fit distribution and determines the OSB and OSS under Neyman allocation directly. When the dataset is not available, stratification is made based on the assumption that the values of the study variable, y, are available as hypothetical realizations of proxy values of y from recent surveys. Thus, it requires certain distributional assumptions about the study variable. At present, it handles stratification for the populations where the study variable follows a continuous distribution, namely, Pareto, Triangular, Right-triangular, Weibull, Gamma, Exponential, Uniform, Normal, Log-normal and Cauchy distributions.
# LazyData: true
# License: GPL-2
# NeedsCompilation: yes
# Depends: R (>= 3.4.0), fitdistrplus, zipfR, stats, actuar, triangle, mc2d
# RoxygenNote: 7.1.2
